awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: A generalizable data framework towards Precision Radiotherapy.
awd_abstract_narration:
In treating cancer patients with radiation therapy, different patients may have different responses to the same type of radiotherapy.  Hence, it is critical to individualize the radiation treatment based on the patient's health data, clinical conditions, as well as response over time.  The goal of this project is to develop a generalizable data framework that can support precision radiotherapy for individual cancer patients.  Specifically, a deep reinforcement learning model will be built and validated with multimodal imaging data acquired during diagnosis, treatment and follow-up of individual patients.  Harmonization of the medical imaging data with genetic and clinical data will create an invaluable repository of knowledge to draw from, while calling for new analytics.  The developed data framework will provide critical clinical decision support for individualized radiotherapy

By leveraging the wealth of data generated in the radiotherapy clinic, the project aims to develop a generalized deep reinforcement learning (DRL) tool for cancer risk stratification.  Based on the DRL tool, an ensemble model will be built to analyze all the data types useful to patient outcome prediction.  The model will be validated with independent datasets to ensure generalization.  To account for information from multiple imaging modalities combined with treatment plans, a multimodal deep reinforcement learning (mDRL) model will be developed and trained with patient data stored in the electronic medical record system, as well as genomic information derived from blood and tissue specimens. The detection tool will be used in both lung cancer and colorectal cancer patients.  Generalization to a variety of other cancers will be possible once the tools become available to the clinical research community.  The ensemble model will allow integrated analysis of multiple data types recorded along the patient outcome trajectory, provide better discrimination between tumor phenotypes and superior predictive power. The framework will be designed to coordinate and synthesize various types of evidence and measurements into scores for the objective assessment and quantification of outcomes and endpoints. This strategy will ultimately provide novel patient re-stratification and support clinical decisions for highly individualized patient management.

por.por_cntn:
New quantitative biomarkers are being inspired by data-driven insights obtained by radiomic analyses performed in patients with cancer. As most approaches are limited to a single mode of data, integrative approaches that inform across modalities are needed but are currently not fully developed. Multimodal integration of molecular diagnostics, radiological and histological imaging, together with clinical data presents opportunities to advance precision oncology. Because many medical data sets are sparse and partially available for use by machine and deep learning techniques, there are a number of significant challenges ahead. Our work has faced some of these challenges, and specifically the problem of combining multiple types of medical imaging measurements used in diagnostic stages of lung cancer patients, and the problem of selecting the most significant information that the image features bring when associated to specific clinical characteristics. This effort has required a combined use of data engineering, computational methods for analysis of heterogeneous data and design of synergistic data models.

Our opinion on the optimal synthesis of all the complementary modalities of data with emerging multimodal artificial intelligence methods is limited to the data sets that were analyzed, but promises to advance along some of the directions we have suggested toward a reimagined class of multimodal biomarkers transforming the field of precision oncology in the coming future. We found that there is substantial room for improving the accuracy of radiomic modeling of image data combined with clinical information and provided an example of application with two data sets obtained in different conditions. The heterogeneity of the data has determined complexities that in part were solved in an innovative way but in part have also generated uncertainty and ambiguity that call for further work. The performance of the models is directly linked to the size and quality of the data, but in order to provide robust inference such as predictive learning or classification, there is a strong priority that must be assigned to data harmonization and model selection aimed at integrating heterogeneous information and delivering explainable approaches.  

Various learning strategies exist and are currently in use for building  integrative (clinic-radiomic) models and delivering accuracy gains in classification and prediction tasks. In most of such learning methods the  focus should be on the significance of results obtained by using multimodality in a synergistic way to allow the radiomics' unveiled potential to be explained. Our study has progressed in this direction by pointing out some of the existing critical data bottlenecks.
